prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in philosophy would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in philosophy would. Calculate the temperature of the universe at an age of 380,000 years after the Big Bang, given that the cosmic microwave background radiation has a present-day temperature of approximately 6.3 Kelvin. Additionally, please select the option from the given choices that you believe is closest to the correct answer!

A. 3931.9 kelvin
B. 4523.6 kelvin
C. 3749.1 kelvin
D. 6936.3 kelvin

Answer:
gpt_response:
To calculate the temperature of the universe at an age of 380,000 years after the Big Bang, we can use the fact that the cosmic microwave background radiation has a present-day temperature of approximately 6.3 Kelvin. 

The temperature of the universe at a given age can be determined by using the relationship between temperature and time in the framework of the standard cosmological model. This relationship is given by the formula T(t) = T0 * (1 + z), where T(t) is the temperature of the universe at time t, T0 is the present-day temperature of the CMB (6.3 Kelvin), and z is the redshift.

At an age of 380,000 years after the Big Bang, the redshift z can be calculated as z = (t/t0)^(1/2) - 1, where t0 is the age of the universe today (approximately 13.8 billion years). Plugging in the values, we find z ≈ 1089. 

Using the formula T(t) = T0 * (1 + z), we can calculate the temperature of the universe at 380,000 years after the Big Bang as T(380,000 years) = 6.3 Kelvin * (1 + 1089) ≈ 6936.3 Kelvin.

Therefore, the closest option to the correct answer is:

D. 6936.3 kelvin
